dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER RUMBLES and LIGHTNING FLASHES... YOUNG LAWRENCE, a raven-haired youth, 10 years old, sits in his bed, looking fearfully to the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the STORM HEARD raging outside, Young Lawrence peers out into the HALLWAY. A man's ANGUISHED CRY is HEARD, but it's lost in the SOUND of THUNDER. Was it imagined? Young Lawrence, in a night~-shirt, starts tentatively dow the long, dark hall of this opulent, Victorian MANOR HOUS LIGHTNING illuminates many big game, ANIMAL HEAD TROPHIES mounted one-after-another: TIGER... ELEPHANT... LION... Young Lawrence walks, trying to ignore the freakish table

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE HALL
dialogues.text: Young Lawrence slows, looking ahead to... a DOOR ajar. LIQUID pools out from beneath, like black molasses. Young Lawrence moves to push the DOOR OPEN...

dialogues.speaker: IN THIS MASTER BEDROOM
dialogues.text: A MAN is slumped on his knees, weeping, cradling the FIGU of a WOMAN. He lets out another CRY of anguish!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Father... ? The man, SIR JOHN TALBOT, 40, looks to see Young Lawrence Sir John is in agony, tears streaming down his face. The cradled WOMAN'S ARM falls free, dangling limply, the wrist slit; gashed wide with BLOOD FLOWING to the floor. Young Lawrence stumbles back in horror... Falling against his older brother, BENJAMIN, 12, arriving the doorway. Benjamin, likewise terrified, raises a brigh OIL LANTERN to the room just as BOOMING THUNDER is HEARD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stately MANSION and surrounding countryside are glimp in brilliant LIGHTNING. THUNDER ECHOES as we... SOAR UP into the TEMPEST! CAMERA Z00MS: through and beyon roiling STORM CLOUDS... to find a FULL MOON shining down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: a stage-craft FULL MOON backlit by flickering gaslight within a painted BACKDROP of crooked trees and g sky. INTO FRAME steps handsome LAWRENCE TALBOT, mid-30's.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (as Hamlet) To be or not to be. That is the question. Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer, The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune... Other ACTORS are SILHOUETTED in nearby SHADOWS. COSTUMED Lawrence walks to centerstage, passionate eyes gleaming.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Or take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them. To die: to sleep. No more; and by a sleep to say we end... IN THE AUDIENCE: wealthy WEST-ENDERS watch, enthralled.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks, That flesh is heir to: 'tis a consummation, Devoutly to be wish'd. To die...

dialogues.speaker: EE DISTRICT
dialogues.text: TOLLING hauntingly, BIG BEN is faintly seen in the gloom this bleak Victorian horizon of endless BUILDINGS, skelet industrial CRANES and soot-spewing SMOKESTACKS. INSERT TITLE: "London, 1888" While on the near STREETS, THEATER-GOERS pour noisily out from the THEATER into filthy, loud, over-crowded Londonto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eee ONEGHT A boisterous PARTY is HEARD from the other room. Lawrence sits at his DRESSING TABLE, in costume, pouring two stiff DRINKS. He hands one to a tawdry COCKNEY LADY beside him.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Over the lips and through the gums... They drink. Cockney Lady laughs, already drunk. Lawrence pours again while Cockney Lady paws at him amorously. A fatherly, ELDER ACTOR, American, enters from a curtained CHANGING BOOTH, pulling on his jacket, watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few cocktails, Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: A few.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER ACTOR
dialogues.text: Too many?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Et tu, Brute?

dialogues.speaker: ELDER ACTOR
dialogues.text: No. Indulge, by all means. Just do not forget yourself. Lawrence toasts his own REFLECTION in his MIRROR.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I make no promises.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER ACTOR
dialogues.text: The occasion is in the other room. Bring your new... friend. Elder Actor exits. Lawrence extricates himself from Cockn Lady's grasp, kissing her hand as he stands.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, dear, while I dress.

dialogues.speaker: COCKNEY LADY
dialogues.text: Dress. Undress. Whichever you like. She smokes. Lawrence begins changing from his COSTUME. Behind, the DOOR opens as a lovely woman, GWEN CONLIFFE, looks in, nervous. She KNOCKS, clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon, sir... I... Lawrence is taking off his SHIRT as he looks over. Gwen is stunningly beautiful, in a nice, though plain, DRESS. She tries to avert her eyes from his shirtlessness

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I'm... terribly sorry, but... you are one Mr. Talbot?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Mr. Lawrence Talbot, actor? Lawrence pulls on a SHIRT, buttoning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct again, and while normally I'd be so happy to make. the acquaintance of an admirer as lovely as yourself... (of Cockney Lady) ..-tonight, as you can plainly see...

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: You misunderstand me.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Do I? Well, make it quick. I'm about to have my hands full.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I've come from Talbot Hall. West Blackmoor. My name is Gwen Conliffe. Betrothed to Mr. Benjamin Talbot. Lawrence regards her with a new seriousness. Gwen nods. Gwen makes way as Lawrence shows Cockney Woman out the do

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My brother's fiance? Lawrence considers, looks to Cockney Lady.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: A moment alone, please...

dialogues.speaker: COCKNEY LADY
dialogues.text: What's all this about?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Go entertain yourself. I'll collect you momentarily.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: So, Miss Conliffe... what brings you here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: You've had no letter from Benjamin lately, though you expected one. Forgive my reading them, but your last correspondence with him told me you'd be in London now. (troubled pause) The reason there's been no letter... Benjamin is gone. He's disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Disappeared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For almost a month now, without a trace. And there's been a killing in Blackmoor; an unspeakable murder. All the while, a certain woman is at the center of it. Because of her, propriety forbids me from saying anything more. (pause) I come to ask for your help.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My father. He knows you came?

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: He knows.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: He asks this? My father?

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I ask. I pray you will return to Talbot Hall. } Lawrence turns away, sullen, slowly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: You must. Please. How... how can I express what heartache it's been...?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Tonight was our last performance before returning to New York. ! Besides which, whatever this is... i what help could I be in any of it?

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: With respect, where else would you have me turn? It is your family in dire need of you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you've wasted your time. For my own reasons, I will never go back to Blackmoor. I'm afraid that's | my final word. Gwen stares sadly down in weary despair.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Well, then. There's nothing more to say. Except thank you for hearing me, Mr. Talbot.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lawrence watches as Gwen crosses. She halts at the door. GWEN . I know you've been away for nearly a lifetime. Still... he is your blood. Your only brother. Gwen goes, SHUTS the DOOR. Lawrence stands alone, miserab cur To:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hello...?! Ahead, within a CIRCLE of huge, weathered and ancient STO MONOLITHS jutting upwards from the ground, Lawrence nears A lone MAN in rural attire, standing with his back to us.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Benjamin, is that you? Ben...? As Lawrence approaches, the MAN TURNS to REVEAL... A FACELESS VISAGE of unbroken flesh stretched ‘taut acros SKULL of empty EYE SOCKETS and gaping maw!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Lord... what a dream. You awake? Cockney Lady GROANS sleepily, stirring...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I dreamt I was in a fog, and... Cockney Lady TURNS, showing a GHOULISH SKULL-FACE devoid features -- SHRIEKING -- her TEETH GNASHING!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems Lawrence awakens for real this time, sweaty, gasping. As he looks to Cockney Lady who lies facing away beside h he scrambles from the bed, backing fearfully to the wall.

Lawrence goes to the roof's edge. He takes out a BOTTLE, drinks. He stares across the dark London CITYSCAPE set against the aborning, orange SUNRISE. His mind is trouble

STATION ATTENDANTS help transport the TRUNKS insi Other ACTORS slap Lawrence on the hack, wishing him well, Elder Actor comes to firmly shake Lawrence's hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER ACTOR
dialogues.text: We'll do the best we can without you. It's right this; you going home.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No home of mine, but I'm going. Hard to believe, one long day's journey takes me back 20 years.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER ACTOR
dialogues.text: Good luck. See you in New York. Lawrence nods, waves as he crosses the STREET... This is post-Industrial-Revolution London, with the SOUND of INDUSTRY echoing in the sooty air; London as the cente of the universe. Streets bustle with hurried GENTLEMEN an LADIES, shouting HAWKERS, dirt-poor WAYWARD YOUTHS and BEGGARS. As Lawrence reaches a waiting four-horse CARRIAG the DRIVER opens the passenger door. Lawrence climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: At one exotically decorated WAGON, an ancient, female fortune-teller, OLD MALEVA, steps out, sensing something. Stooped Old Maleva hobbles purposefully across the encampment, past other TRIBE MEMBERS who respectfully mak way. She reaches a vantage point from where she can SEE.. The DISTANT ROADWAY where Lawrence's carriage is passing. Old Maleva's piercing eyes narrow, fixated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage at last passes under a vine-entangled STONE GATEWAY with a barely discernible "TALBOT" hewn into it. The long, ESTATE ROAD ahead is canopied by mighty TREES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: —_— BL MONTAGE ENDS Amidst once-impressive, now-neglected ORCHARDS... TALBOT MANSION looms; majestic, though it's glory days ar long past. Two-storied. Two wings. Weathered and aged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the carriage heading away in the B.G., Lawrence sets down his TWO SUITCASES. He gathers his nerve, straighteni his clothing and hair. Hesitant, he KNOCKS, entering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOOR CREAKS, as Lawrence enters. He passes through the wood-paneled ENTRY PARLOR, CROSSING into the giant, Victorian-Gothic GRAND HALL. It's a cavernous room, with walls covered floor-to-ceilin in TAPESTRIES, PAINTINGS and all manner of displayed WEAPONRY; RIFLES, LANCES, SHIELDS and crossed SWORDS. Across the way, two STAIRCASES combine at a LANDING to le up to the West and East Wing BALCONIES of the second-stor Lawrence crosses, FOOTSTEPS ECHOING. There is a look and feel here of cobwebby, frayed-edged, smoke-darkened gloom and decay, as there will be everywhere throughout Talbot House. Gothic indeed. Everywhere, magnificence wanes. Lawrence comes to stand before the Grand Hall's massive FIREPLACE, staring up at the OIL PAINTING hanging above.. A PORTRAIT of his MOTHER; a youthful, olive-skinned beaut standing on the moors, her dress and raven hair flowing.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "I will arise and go to my father, and I will say unto him...!" Ris reverie broken, Lawrence turns to see... Grey-haired, dashingly handsome SIR JOHN TALBOT, mid-60's striding down the STAIRCASE, his mellifluous voice boomin

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: "Father, I have sinned against heaven, and before thee! And I am no more worthy to be called thy son; make me as one of thy hired servants!" Sir John reaches the bottom of the stairs, followed by hi ioyal DOG, an old hunting hound, SAMSON. Sir John is an imposing presence; a WELL-DRESSED man of the gentry, desp the odd worn cuff here and loose seam there.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: And lo and behold, here he stands: [ the Prodigal Son returned. Shall I i have my own robe brought to be placed upon your shoulders? Rings for your fingers and shoes your feet? Shall I kili the fatted calf?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Don't go to any trouble on my account.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Come, let me see you. Let me look at { what kind of man you've become. Lawrence walks to face Sir John, clears his dry throat. i

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hello, Father.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Lawrence. They look at each other, no more than ten feet between th silence hanging like a challenge. A chilly reunion.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Words fail me. When your telegram arrived to say you were coming, I couldn't bring myself to believe it. I've grown so accustomed to thinking I would never lay eyes on you again.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: As have I. Sir John SMILES wryly, walks to cross the vast room.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Of course, to be clear... it wasn't my idea to send for you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have imagined so.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Not that you're not welcome, of course! We'll make room for you... (to his :DOG) -+-won't we, boy? It's only that... I simply can't help wondering... Sir John yanks a dusty, tasseled BELL PULL several times.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: What difference could possibly be made by your being here? A fair question, I think. Lawrence considers, restraining his anger.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'll do whatever I can, I suppose, to aid my missing brother...

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: How noble you are!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Although, knowing so little yet, how can I give the answer you seem to want from me, Father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ll.

dialogues.text: (disgruntled) Where in the hell...? Entering through one ARCHWAY beneath the STAIRS, comes th balding and pasty butler, KENDALL, exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: KENDALL
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir John, yes. Here I am.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Wonderful, Kendall. Lawrence here will be our guest for... however long. Take his things up. Have Gwen meet us in the drawing room. cur To:

dialogues.text: EEE EEE —E——EYr Eee In the dark, cluttered, high-ceilinged DRAWING ROOM, Sir John pours much SCOTCH into TWO GLASSES on a LIQUOR TRAY.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Blackmoor's troubles began the day the wandering caravan arrived. Late- winter, ten months ago. Lawrence looks up at ANIMAL HEAD TROPHIES, SAFARI PHOTOS, and WORLD MAPS adorning the walls. Sir John places one drink on a TABLE near Lawrence, goes to sit in a CHAIR by the blazing FIREPLACE which Samson lies near.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: The Gypsies are quite willing to make a living from us; telling fortunes, trading and peddling goods. But, since many villagers still believe all Gypsies to be witches, a distance is kept. Although... it is rumored that, amongst the gentlemen of Blackmoor... Lawrence looks at one PHOTOGRAPH: of YOUNG LAWRENCE and YOUNG BENJAMIN standing with MOTHER and SIR JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Some men of questionable morals, upon a hunting excursion, or out for an evening's constitutional, may discreetly make their way to the Gypsy encampment. There they are welcomed to partake of wine, women and song. Well... maybe not song. At the DOORWAY, Gwen gives a small cough, entering timidl There's no denying her fair beauty. Samson goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Good evening. Sir John stands to be polite...

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Hello, Gwen. -..and immediately sits back down. Lawrence gives a nod.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I didn't expect you'd come. Please... don't let me interrupt. Gwen pets Samson. She crosses to a corner, looking small.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Six weeks ago, a Gypsy named Victor; a blackguard and thieving criminal, finished serving a lengthy prison term in London. He returned to the tribe, only to find his Gypsy wife far along in a pregnancy.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: The child was not his?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: His absence was too great. And so, this Victor dragged the unfortunate woman, Carmilla, into the village. He brought her before our Justice of the Peace, saying Blackmoor parish owed him justice. A CLOCK begins CHIMING. 7:00. Sir John stands.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Seven o'clock already. We must leave.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Leave? Where are we...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir John's already striding out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ——— OO EE mR TO ON EGHT Sir John walks from TALBOT HOUSE. Lawrence and Gwen follo ON THE LAWN, ahead, a STABLE BOY brings THREE HORSES.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Why would this husband go outside his tribe? Unless, he felt the village did the wrong to him.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Exactly. Victor had beaten a confession out of his wife. She told how her secret lover was one of the men of Blackmoor.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: She will not say who it is.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: For which she's spent the last month and a half jailed; to be held until she tells his name.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You still haven't said what all this has to do with Benjamin. Gwen's troubled, unable to bring herself to say it. . Lawrence sees this. Sir John is likewise saddened...

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Benjamin is suspected.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: As the father? It cannot be true.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Squire Strickland has called a Public Hearing for tonight. I must be there to speak for your brother. Sir Lawrence and Gwen go to take their horses' reins. Sir John climbs ably up onto his great, WHITE STALLION. Stable Boy gives Gwen a boost as she mounts her horse.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: You can still ride can't you, Lawrence? Sir John and Gwen ride towards the ESTATE ROAD. Sighing, Lawrence takes his horse, climbs expertly on. He rides.

His WIFE joins him, cradling their infant CHILD.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JAILHOUSE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Strickland surveys the crowd, raises a hand. CROWD QUIETS

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: My friends... we all know why we are gathered here. (pointing down) This man has suffered an injustice...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: AT THE FRONT OF THE CROWD, given wide berth by VILLAGERS, stands VICTOR, Carmilla's thuggish, Gypsy husband, wearin an EYEPATCH. He's flanked by Old Maleva, the fortune teller, and BELA, the gaunt, waxen-skinned Gypsy Chief.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: A great wrong was done to him. Done by this woman... his own wife! Carmilla hangs her head, her features bathed in cold swea

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: She carries a bastard child conceived in the sinful act of adultery.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: The CROWD MURMURS, agitated. Beneath the TAVERN'S "Sword God" SIGN, several of the town's more elderly and most wealthy GENTRY stand watching: the distinguished DOCTOR LLOYD; the broad-shouldered, walrus-moustached COLONEL MONTFORD; and the wizened, dour-faced PASTOR FISK. Other plump, drunken LAND OWNERS stand amongst them, DRINKING.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JAILHOUSE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Strickland plays to the cheap seats always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She refuses to say who in Blackmoor Village is the father. Why is that? Has it something to do with the full moon evening, when blood and gut were spilled onto the moor!? And what about the note; secretly nailed to this very door in the dead of night one day later...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strickland thrusts out a PIECE of PAPER... A scrawled NOTE and DRAWING of a PENTAGRAM: "RELEASE HER

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: A threat made against us all, with the next full moon tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: Beyond the ANGRY CROWD, lanky CONSTABLE NYE (seen in the FLASHBACK) arrives on his BICYCLE, PIPE in mouth.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Who made the threat? For us to find the truth, she must confess her fellow adulterers name! As the CROWD VOICES assent, Strickland glances to Sir Joh

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: UNDER THE STATUE, at the CACOPHONOUS center of the SHOUTI CROWD, Lawrence and Gwen look around in despair.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JAILHOUSE STAIRS
dialogues.text: Sir John steps forward, facing the gathering, raising his hands. The CROWD begins QUIETING, respectfully.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Please, if I may...! You all know me. You know the Talbots have and always will be one of the pillars of this community. JI am an honorable man. As such, I must ask again... by what law, Squire Strickland, is this woman held, when adultery is no crime?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Yes, well... I'm not surprised you'd like to see her freed and forgotten, Sir John. Wasn't it your son said to have frequented the Gypsy camp? (more)

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Your son; Benjamin, who was witnessed in heated arguments with this woman, and who visited her while she was jailed...?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: What kind of man are you, to make such accusations against my son?!

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: These are facts, not accusations. The crime is economic! Should this forgiving husband be left unfairly responsible for the financial burden of the bastard child? I think not.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: That is the reason you pretend so you may exert your puritanical will. You wish to disgrace whoever dared to have relations with a lowly Gypsy! So you overstep the bounds of your authority by jailing her, while you slander my family's good name!

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: If that is what you truly believe, let the debate be opened to all... {addressing the CROWD) If there is anyone who also feels this woman is.the aggrieved party, say so now! Make yourself heard!

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Except who would dare speak against you, aS you are principal landowner and Justice of the Peace?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Yes, many are indebted to me... but everyone knows I am a fair and open-minded man. They know they can speak freely, so... (addressing CROWD) Again; if you side with her, as Sir John does, speak! You think I am unjust? I Beg you, raise your voice!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: UNDER THE STATUE, Lawrence and Gwen look to the surroundi crowd as EVERYONE grows HUSH. AT THE BLACKSMITH SHOPPE, James Fitzgerald watches, empathetic. He sets his jaw, steps forward, about to spea His WIFE reaches to stop him. He sees the fear in her eye

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: AT THE TAVERN, the GENTRY exchange sheepish looks (excep stone-faced Fisk), knowing they will not speak out.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE JAILHOUSE STAIRS
dialogues.text: In the silence, Carmilla shuts her eyes, shedding a tear. Strickland, arms out, turns to Sir John.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: A telling silence. Deafeningly so. Sir John can say nothing more, solemnly defeated.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from across the square) My brother is innocent!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: EVERYONE TURNS en masse, looking... UNDER THE STATUE, Lawrence stands at Gwen's side.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I am Lawrence Talbot, and I would stake my life that Benjamin is not the father. Whoever is... can't you see she's trying to protect you...?! (imploringly, to VILLAGERS) How can you keep silent while she suffers this way, all to save you from harm? I beg you, reveal yourself ALL AROUND Lawrence and Gwen, not one person speaks. No o

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Another heartfelt, familial plea. Alas, met aiso with an empty sound. (turns to Carmilla) If she will not tell, so be it! We hold her longer still! As the Jailer steps forward... Carmilla stands, in shackles, tearful.

dialogues.speaker: CARMILLA
dialogues.text: No! No more! I'll tell... The GASPING CROWD returns all attention to Carmilla.

dialogues.speaker: CARMILLA
dialogues.text: I'll tell you all! I'll keep the secret no longer! The CROWD'S QUIETING as Carmilla looks to the apprehensiv Sir John. She wipes tears, looks out, gathering courage..

dialogues.speaker: CARMILLA
dialogues.text: It is Benjamin... Benjamin Talbot. You have my confession. As the CROWD REACTS, EVERYONE TALKING... SHOUTING... i AT THE BASE OF THE STAIRS, Victor's enraged, charging up Stairs towards Carmilla! The Jailer steps up to block the way -~ shoves Victor back! Bela comes to restrain Victor. Strickland's smiling, triumphant. He nods... The Jailer walks to take Carmilla's arm, pulling her up t steps. Sir John bows his head, stricken, despairing.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SQUARE
dialogues.text: UNDER THE STATUE, Lawrence and Gwen are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: No! It's... it's not true. Gwen climbs down, distraught, PUSHING through...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Gwen! Gwen! She SHOVES past villagers, running away into the CROWD. Cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoke-filled meeting of.town elders. Strickland, Doctor Lloyd and Colonel Montford sit at a TABLE, drinking. Othe fat LAND OWNERS smoke, drink and whisper amongst themselv

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MONTFORD
dialogues.text: Tomorrow comes the full moon. Do you let the whore go or not?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: If I'm permitted to speak in my good | friend Sir John's defense... The BARKEEP serves more BOOZE. Sir John is seated by the FIREPLACE, staring into his MUG, brooding forlornly. i i

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: You needn't defend anyone, Doctor. i We're all on the same side. I more i than anyone wish Ben would appear. |

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MONTFORD
dialogues.text: You know how it looks, Sir John. There are those who believe Benjamin's hiding away, till she's released and the gypsies go. Even more think he is the murderer...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pastor Fisk

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn what people think! To hell with them all!

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MONTFORD
dialogues.text: W...well.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: (to Strickland) Still, it does seem your crusade has reached its end, Squire, with the man she's implicated nowhere to be found.

dialogues.speaker: BARKEEPER
dialogues.text: I know where he is! You want to know?! That lost soul's spellbound in her curse; out in the wilderness somewhere, living like a mad animal... till the full moon calls him again to do her red work! You'll see, tomorrow night! observes, by the BAR where Constable Nye leans.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE NYE
dialogues.text: Please do keep that supernatural claptrap to yourself!

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR FISK
dialogues.text: No. There may be something to it. EVERYONE looks to spooky Pastor Fisk, QUIETING.

dialogues.speaker: PASTOR FISK
dialogues.text: The devil is able to touch our world. There are Such demons that walk like men, and men who walk like demons. Silence lingers, the FIRE HEARD CRACKLING.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not certain what that means, but if she's still jailed by the Quarter Sessions, there'll be hell to pay. Beg pardon, Pastor Fisk. (to Strickland) She's made the confession you demanded, hasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MONTFORD
dialogues.text: The note said others will die!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yes, Colonel, but we don't know who left the note, who did the murder, or even if they are the same person!

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Enough. Enough! (sighing deeply) Let the full moon rise and fall. If there's no other killing, Carmilla will be released to her husband. He may deal with her however he sees fit.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: And the child? What if it is truly my grandchild she carries?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: What of it? Once this is done, the tribe will move on. Feel free to follow them if you like, but they will be Blackmoor's problem no longer. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SSS EE EE EEEEEEeEe__ Lawrence rides his horse through low FOG, carries a LANTE Ahead is the fine FRAMEWORK of a far-from-finished HOUSE forest's edge. Lawrence dismounts, bringing the lantern. INSIDE THE FRAMEWORK, Gwen stares up to the STARRY SKY.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My father said I might find you here.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Welcome to... our house. Not yet a home. On the farthest edge of the your family's estate. I used to iaugh that this is as far as I could get Ben to move from Talbot Hall.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Further than I would have expected. Gwen smiles faintly, looks back up. The surrounding WOOD FRAMING describes a large, simple TWO-STORY STRUCTURE.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Not that there's been much work on it. Not lately.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: He'll be back. He will. Gwen's sad, wanting to believe. They walk.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Thank you for what you said tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant it. He was and always will be the good brother. The good son. Unlike myself. OUTSIDE THE FRAME, Gwen and Lawrence walk with the unfinished house behind them, open FIELD before them.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I confess, after meeting you in London, I didn't... hope for much. From your behavior. Your drinking, and that... woman. I...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes. Well, I may be more than I first appear. Or less. They stop, looking to the distant LIGHTS of the GYPSY CAM

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You claimed Benjamin said nothing unusual before he left. Is that the full truth of it? Gwen looks at him, uncertain what to say.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Whatever you're hiding, I hope you'll trust me enough soon to tell me. Behind, a HORSE SNORTS. Lawrence and Gwen turn, startled. Old Maleva and Bela are there on horses, like eerie spect

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hello? What do you want? Old Maleva rides closer. Bela slowly circles, eyeing them Lawrence steps protectively in front of Gwen.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MALEVA
dialogues.text: You. You are the young Talbot?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: In a manner of speaking.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MALEVA
dialogues.text: You should return to wherever you are from. The path you're on leads to the end of you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (unnerved, sarcastic) As much as I'd like to take your advice, I'm afraid I can't. Lawrence is keeping an eye and lantern on Bela. Bela stop

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: You are the fortune teller?

dialogues.speaker: OLD MALEVA
dialogues.text: Maleva the Seer.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Then, see his brother.... my fiance, Benjamin. Please tell us where he is. Old Maleva's piercing eyes fix on Gwen a moment. Suddenly, Old Maleva yanks her horse's reins, riding off. Lawrence aims his lantern up at Bela's glowering face.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You don't say much, do you? Bela kicks his horse, riding to follow Old Maleva. Lawrence and Gwen watch. Old Maleva halts, turning back..

dialogues.speaker: OLD MALEVA
dialogues.text: I will ask the spirits. If they know of your brother... I will find you. Old Maleva rides to follow Bela away into the night. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAY MORN. Constable Nye peddles his BICYCLE fast across the GREAT LAWN. He leaps off, bounding up the STAIRS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: —— ee EE EEE EEE The FRONT DOOR swings wide as Constable Nye storms in, stumbling, GASPING to catch his breath... SHOUTING OUT...

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE NYE
dialogues.text: Disaster! cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — EE RE LBONSE — > MORNING Amongst some gathered VILLAGERS, Lawrence watches as... Carmilla's ENSHROUDED CORPSE, entirely wrapped in CLOTH except for her face, is carried down the STAIRS of the JAILHOUSE, shouldered by SIX GYPSY MEN. A COIN has been placed on each of Carmilla's closed eyes. ON THE STREET, an enclosed GYPSY WAGON awaits. Old Maleva stands with Carmilla's husband, Victor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bela's on horseback. They watch, creepily emotionless, as Carmilla's BODY is loaded into the back of the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Maleva looks up at Lawrence, then climbs in. The wagon's DRIVER begins slowly driving away as Victor, Bela and all the other GYPSIES follow along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ——— ES EEE EE eR TT ALY Lawrence enters. A utilitarian DESK and CABINETS are located across from THREE empty, metal-barred CELLS. Sir John, Constable Nye and Squire Strickland stand at the fi open CELL, where Doctor Lloyd kneels. Jailer's in the B.G

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: She was cold as the grave. The baby was motionless inside her. A NECKLACE Carmilla wore lies on the floor, its AMULET op like a locket, with RED POWDER spilled out from inside it

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: There is a remnant of the Gypsy poison here, whatever it is. Lawrence approaches as Doctor Lloyd rises. Sir John moves past, stepping away, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: It might have been passed to her by someone in the tribe. She might have had it with her the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: CONSTABLE NYE
dialogues.text: Why? Why kill herself now?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Who knows? Abandoned by Benjamin. Deathly afraid, I'm sure, to face her husband's wrath. Whatever her reasons, there's no question she took her own life. (considering) Good riddance. To her and all of them. Sir John slowly turns. He strides back towards Strickland Sir John PUNCHES Strickland! He SWINGS again, but he's grabbed by Lawrence and Doctor Lloyd, held off. Strickland recovers, furious, nose bloodied.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: What the devil... !?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: What's come over you, John?!

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: You might as well have killed her yourself, Strickland, damn you! Sir John pulls free of Dr. Lloyd and Nye, angry.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Tell me... how will my son clear his name!?! Now that she's... she's... (venting rage) How will he ever return to prove his innocence now?! Tell me that. He grabs a CHAIR, HURLS it... SHATTERS the GLASS of a CABINET!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serr EOE Lawrence descends the stairs, slowing as he sees Samson lying on the floor, on his belly, head down. Samson lifts his chin to look at Lawrence, WHIMPERS, lays back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ——— Se EE eEOeee Lawrence enters. A long DINING TABLE stands beneath THREE grand, cobweb-covered CHANDELIERS. Sir John is seated at the far end, feet up, drunk, a half-empty BOTTLE held. Hi untucked shirt bears the TALBOT FAMILY CREST on its pocke

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Ah... Mr. Talbot, Esquire. Just the gentleman I'm looking for... Sir John rises. Lawrence remains by the door.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: I've been meaning to ask you. Explain again exactly how it is you make your living. Pretending you're someone else? Playing at life? How bloody appropriate...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You should rest, Father. You've probably had enough to drink today. Sir John DRINKS. He SLAMS the table with the bottle, drag the bottle along the table as he walks the length of it.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Am I alright, you asked? (more)

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Am I alright?! Good Christ! I want someone to tell me... someone tell me, please... how could this have happened that you are here and he is not? WHERE IS MY SON!? (agonized pause) What wouldn't I give... to have it be you the one missing instead. You do know that, don't you? Lawrence swallows hard, refusing to let out his sorrow.:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Of course I do.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Until yesterday, you were missing. So forgive me if I doubt I'll begin to rely upon you at this late date.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: You are your brother's opposite. Never worth a damn. You're not even man enough to stand up for yourself, are you? Say something. Don't just stand there. Defend yourself, goddamn you! Defend yourself!! Lawrence just clenches his jaw, tears welling up. Sir John's spent, pulls out a CHAIR to sit. Stares forwar

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: Get out of my sight. Lawrence turns to leave, falters upon seeing... THRU THE DOORWAY: Gwen in the HALL, mortified for him.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm sorry, 1... Lawrence struggles mightily to maintain his composure as walks out, passing Gwen, walking on. CuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strickland addresses a handful of VILLAGERS, a few GENTRY amongst them. Constable Nye smokes his PIPE by the door.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Ask me? rink up, I say. Head home. (more)

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND, (CONT.)
dialogues.text: Spend the night behind lock and key, merely as a precaution. That's what I'li be doing, and here's to it... (raises his MUG) An uneventful evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVERYONE toasts, DRINKING. Constable Nye exits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ————————————EO—EE—TEOEOrer ONS ATER TW DUSK NIGHT NEARS. Constable Nye gets onto his BICYCLE. He take a REVOLVER from the POUCH on his handlebars, checks it. He puts the gun back, straightens his hat, nervous. Nye RIDES off through the SQUARE, circling the ANGEL STAT Streets are deserted. SHOPS are CLOSED. WINDOWS SHUTTERED In some of the SECOND STORY WINDOWS, a few VILLAGERS peer out. CURTAINS are pulled SHUT. Everyone's hiding, wary. DOWN THE STREET, as Nye rides by the CHURCH... UNDER THE CHURCH'S ENTRYWAY, Pastor Fisk looks out, watch Nye pass. Fisk shoves the heavy CHURCH DOOR SHUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skies over Talbot Hall darken. Sir John, Doctor Lloyd and Colonel Montford, in heavy JACKETS, walk to their HORSES. Kendall, the butler, follows, overburdened with SHOTGUNS HUNTING BAGS. Lawrence follows Kendail. : Sir John, Dr. Lloyd and Colonel Montford mount. Kendall hands up the guns and supplies. SIR JOHN i We'll keep watch, covering as much | ground as we can till dawn. For no reason whatsoever, I'm certain.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MONTFORD
dialogues.text: I hope to God you're right about that.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: (impassively, to Lawrence) Still. Stay in. Keep this on you. Sir John offers a PISTOL, which Lawrence steps up to acce Sir John, eyes hung-over-bloodshot, doesn't look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: Shall we? Sir John, Dr. Lloyd and Colonel Montford RIDE OFF. Lawrence looks at the gun in hand, looks to Talbot Hall.. Where Gwen stands SILHOUETTED in the front doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FULL MOON edges over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chimney SMOKE WAFTS from a large, thatched-roof PEASANT HOMESTEAD. One PEASANT MALE stands guard, RIFLE in hand.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE PEASANT DWELLING
dialogues.text: FIRE in the FIREPLACE. PEASANT FAMILIES; FATHERS, MOTHERS and many CHILDREN, are crowded into this common dwelling, EATING at the rough-hewn, communal TABLE. Everyone's quie tense. Several of the MEN share worried glances. MANY RIFLES are propped up by the FRONT DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gwen enters to find Lawrence looking up at his MOTHER'S PORTRAIT. After a moment, Lawrence turns to see Gwen.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Tell me about her.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (looks to PAINTING) The kindest soul. Without equal. (remembering) We spent endless hours together in this very room. Playing music... reading books aloud, and plays. Acting out favorite scenes. She was able to fill this house with warmth, if you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: What happened? I mean... do not say, if you feel you cannot. It's just... Ben and your father refuse to speak of her. Lawrence looks to Gwen, his mood darkening.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE UPSTAIRS HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Lawrence and Gwen appear in the DOORWAY of an EMPTY ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: This was my bedroom. When I was ten years old, one night, a storm woke me. I started down the hallway... He leads Gwen down the hall, past the dusty audience of ANIMAL HEAD TROPHIES (familiar from the OPENING SCENE) .  30.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE HALL
dialogues.text: Lawrence approaches the closed DOOR of the MASTER BE:DROO

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My parents' bedroom. There was something liquid on the floor. Lawrence steps up, uses one finger to push the DOOR OPEN. He stares into the DARK BEDROOM.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My father held her as she died. She'd killed herself. Slit her wrists. Blood was... everywhere. (pause) I never even knew why she did it.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I... didn't know. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STAIRS, GRAND HALL
dialogues.text: Lawrence, still lost in remembrance, descends with Gwen.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: There's a lot I don't remember. My mind was affected, they say. (troubled pause) I spent months in an insane asylum, in London. Father sent me. Till I could cope with my mother's death. They return to the GRAND HALL. Gwen's listening, saddened

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: In that nightmare; the asylum... I lived strapped down. Drugged. Lost amongst the screaming mad. It truly was a hell. That much I recall. (pause) I was returned home, "cured." I lasted five more years till I ran away, at fifteen. To America. (looking around) I've spend my whole life traveling the world so I would be anywhere but here, and yet... here I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Constable Nye, smoking his pipe, rides his bike on Blackm Road, through the wasteland moors. A LANTERN hangs from h handlebars. He stops to check his POCKET WATCH. It's 12:2  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the FULL MOON high in the night sky... The quiet of the deep forest is broken by the SOUND of SOMETHING MOVING this way, SNAPPING BRANCHES and SHOVING THROUGH FOLIAGE as it goes. We catch only the merest GLIMPSE of a BESTIAL SHADOW; some CREATURE, MOVING FAST..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are a BEAST on two feet; our animalistic BREATHING HEA as we CHARGE HEADLONG through the vine-ensnarled FOREST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gwen stands facing away from Lawrence, greatly troubled.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: I want to confide in you, Lawrence. I have not told anyone. Not even your father. (pause) From the moment Carmilla was jailed, Benjamin was not himself. He... Gwen hesitates as FOOTSTEPS are HEARD. ACROSS THE ROOM, Kendall walks to tend to the FIREPLACE.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: Not here. Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camp is quiet, with LIGHTS in the windows of only a f of the WAGONS. Campfires are out, still smoldering. SHADOWS move across one large TENT from inside...

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GYPSY TENT
dialogues.text: TWO FEMALE GYPSIES sit watching a THIRD lay TAROT CARDS o a crooked TABLE. A LANTERN throws their SHADOWS as Third Gypsy speaks an unintelligible INCANTATION over each card

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We LOOK OUT from dense foliage, WATCHING the GYPSY CAMP. We MOVE FORWARD... SEEING the SHADOWS against the TENT ah

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GYPSY TENT
dialogues.text: Third Gypsy keeps intoning, laying down card after card. She stops, looking to the other two Gypsy women, nervous. Third Gypsy WHISPERS as she slowly turns one more CARD... The GRIM REAPER; death card. Third Gypsy stands, afraid.  32.

dialogues.text: (to Dr. Lloyd) and Dr. Lloyd, and CHAIRS. the tabletop. TEA on fine CHINA. We've searched from the forests to the moors. Each of us tread every inch of our lands and found no evidence of any “unwelcome visitor."

dialogues.text: (accepting TEA) Yes, it's one thing if this man-beast comes from... out there somewhere... (WAVING to the distance) Quite another if it is amongst us. Lloyd and Strickland share a look, mulling this unhappily

dialogues.text: Could be anyone. Could be someone's cursed and doesn't even know it. (staring off, fretting) A werewolf... he's the worst of man and beast; killing not for food or in self-defense, but for killing's sake. Sir John and Lawrence arrive, dismounting.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Half the village has left for the city already. Everyone who remains is at each other's throat.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: I stitched up five drunken brawlers in the village last night alone.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Killing this creature means saving our community from itself. GUNFIRE is HEARD as training continues in the BACKGROUND. SOMEONE is RIDING THIS WAY from far across the property.

dialogues.text: No more word from London?

dialogues.text: No officer has hurried to take Constable Nye's position, not surprisingly, considering the manner in which it was vacated.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: London sends promises of help; never the help itself. We're on our own.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: They most likely think us mad. TI think us mad, so why shouldn't they?

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: Yes, it all seems laughable in the light of day, but wait till when the full moon returns. All the men nod, agreeing. Kendall nods, still serving.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL MONTFORD
dialogues.text: On that midnight hour, the shadow of the monster will fall upon us again.

dialogues.speaker: SIR JOHN
dialogues.text: I can't help wondering how different things might be except for the actions of certain persons.

dialogues.speaker: STRICKLAND
dialogues.text: (bristling) If you refer to certain persons who are still unaccounted for, I'm inclined to agree. Sir John looks likely to swing again. Strickland stands.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Stop this, please.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD
dialogues.text: Quite. We've all of us ended up in this together. Leave it at that. Sir John backs down, fists clenched. He walks, going off watch the continuing RIDING and PISTOL TARGET-PRACTICE.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: We'll be ready. Whatever creature it is will be defeated.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR LLOYD

dialogues.text: You... you know I cannot...

dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GWEN
dialogues.text: We don't know. We may never.
